chapter.htmlHeader: How should I assess a person reporting halitosis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
If a person presents with self-reported halitosis, assess the person to confirm the diagnosis and identify any underlying cause.

  • Ask the person about:
    • Their own perception of the halitosis, including the impact on their quality of life (education, work, and social activities, relationships, anxiety and mood), and changes in behaviour (such as covering the mouth when talking and avoiding social interactions). Note: be aware that the person's own assessment of their breath is not always reliable.
    • The severity, timing during the day, and duration of symptoms, for example relation to certain foods or drinks, or following periods of hunger or starvation (may suggest physiological halitosis).
    • Additional symptoms such as dry mouth (which can lead to decreased taste sensation and difficulty in swallowing), mouth breathing, nasal discharge or obstruction, loss of sense of smell, cough, or weight loss.
    • Possible lifestyle factors, such as diet, smoking, and alcohol intake.
    • Dental history and oral hygiene routine, such as:
      • History of dental surgery including faulty restorations or ill-fitting prostheses.
      • Oral hygiene measures and frequency of toothbrushing, inter-dental cleaning, tongue cleaning, and use of mouthwashes/chewing gums/mints/sprays.
      • Use of a dental prosthesis (denture, orthodontic appliance, bridge); denture hygiene (if appropriate), including whether dentures are taken out at night and cleaned regularly.
      • Frequency of routine dental checks and any dental hygienist input.
    • Any medical history, including possible extra-oral causes of halitosis.
    • Any medications or recreational drugs which may cause or contribute to halitosis.
    • Any concerns from the person's partner, friends, or family members; their perception of the halitosis; and how they feel it is affecting the person (if possible and appropriate).
  • Confirm that objective halitosis is present by assessing the person's breath (so-called 'organoleptic testing').
    • Ideally, the person should not wear fragrances prior to the assessment. In addition, the person should not consume odiferous foods or drinks for 48 hours (and should ideally only drink water on the morning of the assessment); should not smoke for 12 hours; and should omit their usual oral hygiene routine for 24 hours prior to the assessment. This may be difficult to achieve in primary care.
    • Ask the person to breathe out of their mouth (pinching the nose), and then to breathe out of their nose (with the mouth closed), and smell the person's exhaled breath. Halitosis is likely to be:
      • Oral or pharyngeal in origin — if malodour is detected from the mouth but not from the nose.
      • Nasal or sinus in origin — if malodour is detected from the nose but not from the mouth.
      • Systemic in origin — if malodour from the nose and mouth are of equal intensity (rare).
    • Consider repeating the assessment on two or three occasions if no halitosis is detected on the initial examination.
      • Consider a diagnosis of pseudo-halitosis or halitophobia if halitosis is not detected on any occasion.
  • Assess the person's oral health.
    • Examine the person's teeth, tongue, and oral cavity to assess for oral causes of halitosis, such as malaligned teeth, dental caries, periodontal disease, tongue coating, and plaque.
      • Be aware that tongue coating may be a cause of halitosis even in people with otherwise good dental hygiene and oral health.
      • Consider gently scraping the posterior tongue area (for example, with a clean plastic spoon), as the odour from the scraping is generally similar to overall mouth odour.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on assessment of a person with halitosis are largely based on expert opinion in an international consensus document Halitosis management by the general dental practitioner - results of an international consensus workshop [Seemann et al, 2014] and expert opinion in review articles on halitosis [Eli et al, 2001; Porter and Scully, 2006; Vandekerckhove et al, 2009; Bollen and Beikler, 2012; Scully and Greenman, 2012; Zalewska et al, 2012; Aydin, 2014; Mokeem, 2014; Singh, 2015; De Geest, 2016; Kapoor, 2016].

Assessing clinical features on history-taking

  • The recommendations on relevant clinical features is based on expert opinion in the international consensus document [Seemann et al, 2014] and in review articles [Eli et al, 2001; Porter and Scully, 2006; Aydin, 2014; Singh, 2015; Kapoor, 2016].
    • The examples of possible behavioural changes in people with halitosis which may be a sign of halitophobia are based on expert opinion in a review article [Porter and Scully, 2006].
    • The information that it may be difficult for a person with halitosis to accurately assess the severity of their own oral odour is based on expert opinion in review articles [Eli et al, 2001; Porter and Scully, 2006].
    • The information on additional symptoms to ask about to help indicate an underlying oral or extra-oral cause is based on expert opinion in a review article [Kapoor, 2016].
    • The recommendation to ask about dental history and dental prostheses is based on expert opinion in a review article [Kapoor, 2016].
    • The recommendation to ask for a collateral history from partner, friends, or family is based on expert opinion in a review article, which notes that there is interpersonal variation in the emotional reactions to detected odour [Aydin, 2014].

Assessing for objective halitosis ('organoleptic testing')

  • Smelling the person's breath to diagnose halitosis and evaluate its severity is recommended as the gold standard clinical test. It is quick, simple, cheap, and no specific clinical training is needed [Porter and Scully, 2006; Bollen and Beikler, 2012; Scully and Greenman, 2012; Seemann et al, 2014; Singh, 2015; Kapoor, 2016]. An additional benefit is the fact that the human nose can distinguish the largest variety of different odours [De Geest, 2016].
    • The information on the advice for the person to avoid wearing fragrances and ideally only consume water prior to the assessment is based on expert opinion in the international consensus document [Seemann et al, 2014].
    • The information on the advice for the person to avoid odiferous foods, not smoke, and omit their usual oral hygiene measures prior to the assessment is based on expert opinion in the international consensus document [Seemann et al, 2014] and in a review article [Singh, 2015].
    • The information on how to interpret the smell of exhaled air from the mouth and nose is based on expert opinion in review articles [Porter and Scully, 2006; Kapoor, 2016].
    • Expert opinion in a review article notes that there is interpersonal variation in the emotional reactions to detected odour [Aydin, 2014].
  • CKS notes that specialist methods such as gas chromatography or measurement of volatile sulphur compounds are more objective measures of halitosis and may be used in research and specialist clinics [Porter and Scully, 2006; Vandekerckhove et al, 2009]. However, these methods are too impractical, time-consuming, and expensive for routine use in primary care [Porter and Scully, 2006; Mokeem, 2014; De Geest, 2016; Kapoor, 2016].

Assessing clinical features on oral examination

  • The information on the clinical features to assess for on oral examination are based on expert opinion in review articles, which recommend checking for oral conditions that may predispose to bacterial colonization and production of odiferous compounds [Singh, 2015; Kapoor, 2016].
    • The recommendation on how to assess tongue coating is based on expert opinion in a review article [Kapoor, 2016].
